cross_matches.statement_a: 1:** Chronic low-dose THC (≤2.5 mg/day) improves wellbeing via *biphasic CB1 signaling*: G-protein activation (EC50 ~10 nM) dominates at 10–30% occupancy, while β-arrestin recruitment (EC50 >100 nM) i
cross_matches.statement_b: 1:** The biphasic (inverted-U) dose-response of THC occurs because low CB1 occupancy (<20%) preferentially engages Gi/o-ERK-CREB-BDNF signaling, while high occupancy recruits β-arrestin-2, causing rec
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Partial agonism at CB1 maintains receptor sensitivity by favoring G-protein coupling over β-arrestin, preventing desensitization while enhancing tonic endocannabinoid signaling.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: Low-dose THC produces biased signaling at CB1, sustaining Gi/o coupling to ERK/CREB without triggering β-arrestin-mediated internalization, thereby upregulating BDNF.

cross_matches.statement_a: Lithium neuroprotection at low dose (<0.5 mM) primarily via partial GSK3β inhibition (IC50 1-2 mM), stabilizing β-catenin, upregulating BDNF and autophagy.
cross_matches.statement_b: 2:** Neuroprotection at low dose is mediated primarily by indirect GSK-3β inhibition via Akt-Ser9 phosphorylation amplification, with effective EC50 ~0.2–0.5 mM intracellular — achievable at plasma [L
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Li+ mimics Mg2+ uncompetitively at GSK3β active site, reducing phosphorylation of pro-apoptotic substrates proportionally to dose.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: Li⁺ inhibits PP1/PP2A-mediated dephosphorylation of Akt-phosphorylated GSK-3β-Ser9, creating a signal amplification loop where small [Li⁺] produces disproportionate GSK-3β suppression.

cross_matches.statement_a: The therapeutic index of lithium is fundamentally narrow because the Kᵢ for GSK-3β inhibition is only one to two orders of magnitude lower than the concentration that disrupts renal Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase func
cross_matches.statement_b: 4:** The clinical therapeutic index (~2–3) dramatically underestimates the *brain-specific* TI because brain [Li⁺] at toxic plasma levels (~1.5 mM) remains ~1–1.8 mM — still below direct GSK-3β Ki — w
cross_matches.mechanism_a: The neuroprotective ED50 is driven by GSK-3β inhibition (Kᵢ ≈ 1-2 mM, but effective in vivo at lower plasma levels), while the nephrotoxic TD50 is driven by disruption of ion pumps essential for renal
cross_matches.mechanism_b: The organ-specific TI for brain neuroprotection vs. renal toxicity is ~10–20× when indexed to intracellular concentrations rather than plasma.

cross_matches.statement_a: 1:** Chronic low-dose THC (≤2.5 mg/day) improves wellbeing via *biphasic CB1 signaling*: G-protein activation (EC50 ~10 nM) dominates at 10–30% occupancy, while β-arrestin recruitment (EC50 >100 nM) i
cross_matches.statement_b: Aged hippocampus shows pathologically elevated GABAergic tone, such that low-dose THC (CB1 on interneurons) restores balance via disinhibition, specific to aging vs. young.
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Partial agonism at CB1 maintains receptor sensitivity by favoring G-protein coupling over β-arrestin, preventing desensitization while enhancing tonic endocannabinoid signaling.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: Aging ↑perineuronal nets/GABA release elevates inhib tone; low THC reduces it toward youth levels without young overexcitation.

cross_matches.statement_a: Therapeutic index TD50_nephro/ED50_neuro >10, with ED50_neuro ≈0.3 mM serum equiv., TD50>3 mM.
cross_matches.statement_b: 4:** The clinical therapeutic index (~2–3) dramatically underestimates the *brain-specific* TI because brain [Li⁺] at toxic plasma levels (~1.5 mM) remains ~1–1.8 mM — still below direct GSK-3β Ki — w
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Constrained by FDA prior; narrow window emerges from higher renal IMPase sensitivity vs. brain GSK3β.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: The organ-specific TI for brain neuroprotection vs. renal toxicity is ~10–20× when indexed to intracellular concentrations rather than plasma.

cross_matches.statement_a: The dose-response curve for nephrotoxicity follows a Hill coefficient >1 (n ≈ 2–3), reflecting cooperative depletion of inositol pools, creating a steep threshold rather than gradual toxicity onset.
cross_matches.statement_b: 3:** Nephrotoxicity involves a threshold/cooperative mechanism (effective Hill n ≈ 1.5–2.5) because damage requires simultaneous IMPase inhibition (Ki ~0.8 mM), disrupted AQP2 trafficking, and ER stre
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Inositol pool depletion is nonlinear — IMPase inhibition must exceed a threshold before phosphoinositide recycling collapses, producing apparent cooperativity in the toxicity dose-response.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: (effective Hill n ≈ 1.5–2.5) because damage requires simultaneous IMPase inhibition (Ki ~0.8 mM), disrupted AQP2 trafficking, and ER stress — each independently insufficient.

cross_matches.statement_a: The therapeutic index of lithium is fundamentally narrow because the Kᵢ for GSK-3β inhibition is only one to two orders of magnitude lower than the concentration that disrupts renal Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase func

cross_matches.mechanism_b: ENaC admits Li⁺ with P_Li/P_Na ≥1, but basolateral Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase extrudes Li⁺ ~10× slower than Na⁺, causing accumulation to 2–16 mM at 0.8 mM plasma, triggering IMPase inhibition and lysosomal stress.

cross_matches.statement_b: 1:** The biphasic (inverted-U) dose-response of THC occurs because low CB1 occupancy (<20%) preferentially engages Gi/o-ERK-CREB-BDNF signaling, while high occupancy recruits β-arrestin-2, causing rec
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Low-dose THC occupies CB1 without competing with 2-AG, preserving tonic signaling; high-dose THC displaces 2-AG, triggering MAGL-mediated degradation.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: Low-dose THC produces biased signaling at CB1, sustaining Gi/o coupling to ERK/CREB without triggering β-arrestin-mediated internalization, thereby upregulating BDNF.

cross_matches.statement_b: 2:** *Nephrotoxicity arises from intracellular [Li⁺] trapping in renal principal cells (2–20× plasma levels) due to ENaC-mediated uptake and poor Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase efflux, exceeding IMPase Ki (~0.8 mM) an
cross_matches.mechanism_a: : IMPase inhibition depletes phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate (PIP₂), triggering ER stress (e.g., CHOP, XBP1 splicing) in renal cells; neurons mitigate this via Nrf2-driven glutathione synthesis. - *
cross_matches.mechanism_b: ENaC admits Li⁺ with P_Li/P_Na ≥1, but basolateral Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase extrudes Li⁺ ~10× slower than Na⁺, causing accumulation to 2–16 mM at 0.8 mM plasma, triggering IMPase inhibition and lysosomal stress.

cross_matches.statement_a: Therapeutic index TD50_nephro/ED50_neuro >10, with ED50_neuro ≈0.3 mM serum equiv., TD50>3 mM.
cross_matches.statement_b: Dose-discrepancy from PK-driven TI expansion: effective brain TI_GSK3 ~20-50 (ED50_plasma 0.2 mM / TD50_plasma 10 mM), renal TI_ENaC ~2-3 due to 5× accumulation factor.
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Constrained by FDA prior; narrow window emerges from higher renal IMPase sensitivity vs. brain GSK3β.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: Accumulation factor (AF_kidney/AF_brain ~5) × target Ki ratio shrinks apparent plasma TI below prior minimum=10.

cross_matches.statement_a: 3:** The cytotoxic transition occurs NOT at depolarized ΔΨm but at **hyperpolarized** ΔΨm (~-180 mV), where VDAC1 partial closure promotes oligomerization; CBD at ≥5 μM stabilizes closed-state oligome
cross_matches.statement_b: 1:** The neuroprotection-to-cytotoxicity transition follows a cooperative oligomerization threshold: apoptosis requires ≥4 adjacent cofactor-free VDAC1 monomers, so cytotoxicity probability scales as
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Closed VDAC1 exposes oligomerization interfaces (β-strands 1,2,19); CBD's hydrophobic intercalation between monomers stabilizes hexameric pores large enough for cytochrome c (~12 kDa) passage.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: Cofactors sterically shield VDAC1 lateral interfaces; ligand-mediated displacement at high occupancy increases f_free past the percolation threshold for oligomer nucleation, releasing cytochrome c.

cross_matches.statement_b: 2:** *Nephrotoxicity arises from intracellular [Li⁺] trapping in renal principal cells (2–20× plasma levels) due to ENaC-mediated uptake and poor Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase efflux, exceeding IMPase Ki (~0.8 mM) an
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Chronic IMPase block reduces IP1 hydrolysis, depleting inositol for phosphoinositide synthesis needed in proximal tubule cells under hyperosmotic stress.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: ENaC admits Li⁺ with P_Li/P_Na ≥1, but basolateral Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase extrudes Li⁺ ~10× slower than Na⁺, causing accumulation to 2–16 mM at 0.8 mM plasma, triggering IMPase inhibition and lysosomal stress.

cross_matches.statement_a: The dose-response curve for nephrotoxicity follows a Hill coefficient >1 (n ≈ 2–3), reflecting cooperative depletion of inositol pools, creating a steep threshold rather than gradual toxicity onset.
cross_matches.statement_b: Nephrotoxicity exhibits a sharp, non-linear dose-response (Hill coefficient > 1.5) because intracellular Li⁺ accumulation past a critical threshold (~2-3 mM) triggers cooperative, catastrophic events
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Inositol pool depletion is nonlinear — IMPase inhibition must exceed a threshold before phosphoinositide recycling collapses, producing apparent cooperativity in the toxicity dose-response.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: Beyond simple enzyme inhibition, supraphysiological intracellular cation levels trigger stress responses that function as all-or-none switches, amplifying cellular damage in a highly cooperative manne

cross_matches.statement_a: (Supporting SINGULAR thread) Neuronal BDNF/TrkB signaling is potentiated by low-dose lithium via GSK-3β inhibition and CREB activation, providing a robust compensatory pro-survival signal absent in re
cross_matches.statement_b: 2:** Neuroprotection at low dose is mediated primarily by indirect GSK-3β inhibition via Akt-Ser9 phosphorylation amplification, with effective EC50 ~0.2–0.5 mM intracellular — achievable at plasma [L
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Lithium-enhanced BDNF/TrkB signaling activates PI3K/Akt and ERK pathways, which converge on mTOR and Bcl-2 to suppress apoptosis and enhance autophagy, buffering against mild metabolic stress.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: Li⁺ inhibits PP1/PP2A-mediated dephosphorylation of Akt-phosphorylated GSK-3β-Ser9, creating a signal amplification loop where small [Li⁺] produces disproportionate GSK-3β suppression.

cross_matches.statement_a: Cytoprotective CBD (EC50 2-3.7 μM via TRPV1/2) dominates daytime (hyperpolarized ψ closes VDAC1, blocking cytotoxicity); nighttime flip via open VDAC1.
cross_matches.statement_b: The therapeutic window for a neuroprotective VDAC1 ligand like CBD is practically non-existent due to off-target effects. The neuroprotective concentration range (~0.5x Kd ≈ 5.5 µM) is an order of mag
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Low-dose CBD modulates Ca2+/metabolite flux protectively; VDAC1 closure at -180 mV requires >Kd CBD for forced oligomerization.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: The separation between the on-target VDAC1 affinity and off-target CYP3A4 inhibition affinity is insufficient to meet the minimum therapeutic index of 10.

cross_matches.statement_a: THC β-arrestin recruitment EC50 > G-protein EC50 (bias factor ~3-5), so low occupancy (<30%) yields therapeutic cAMP inhibition without GRK2/βarr downregulation.

cross_matches.statement_a: The tolerance crossover point is governed by first-order kinetics: therapeutic window persists while k_recycle + k_synthesis > k_int × fractional_occupancy. For CB1, k_recycle ≈ 0.02 min⁻¹, k_int ≈ 0.

cross_matches.mechanism_b: Low-dose THC produces biased signaling at CB1, sustaining Gi/o coupling to ERK/CREB without triggering β-arrestin-mediated internalization, thereby upregulating BDNF.

cross_matches.statement_a: 3:** The cytotoxic transition occurs NOT at depolarized ΔΨm but at **hyperpolarized** ΔΨm (~-180 mV), where VDAC1 partial closure promotes oligomerization; CBD at ≥5 μM stabilizes closed-state oligome
cross_matches.statement_b: The cytotoxic threshold for VDAC1 ligands scales as Kd × (1 + [HK-II]/Ki_HK) × (Bcl-xL/Bax) × (1 + [tubulin]/Ki_tub), yielding >10× higher thresholds in neurons (TI > 10) vs. cancer cells (TI < 5).
cross_matches.mechanism_a: Closed VDAC1 exposes oligomerization interfaces (β-strands 1,2,19); CBD's hydrophobic intercalation between monomers stabilizes hexameric pores large enough for cytochrome c (~12 kDa) passage.
cross_matches.mechanism_b: HK-II, Bcl-xL, and tubulin act as competitive inhibitors of ligand-induced oligomerization by sequestering VDAC1 monomers; their combined buffering capacity sets the free VDAC1 fraction.

cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: Accumulation factor (AF_kidney/AF_brain ~5) × target Ki ratio shrinks apparent plasma TI below prior minimum=10.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: 3:** The cytotoxic transition occurs NOT at depolarized ΔΨm but at **hyperpolarized** ΔΨm (~-180 mV), where VDAC1 partial closure promotes oligomerization; CBD at ≥5 μM stabilizes closed-state oligome
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: 1:** The neuroprotection-to-cytotoxicity transition follows a cooperative oligomerization threshold: apoptosis requires ≥4 adjacent cofactor-free VDAC1 monomers, so cytotoxicity probability scales as
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Closed VDAC1 exposes oligomerization interfaces (β-strands 1,2,19); CBD's hydrophobic intercalation between monomers stabilizes hexameric pores large enough for cytochrome c (~12 kDa) passage.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: Cofactors sterically shield VDAC1 lateral interfaces; ligand-mediated displacement at high occupancy increases f_free past the percolation threshold for oligomer nucleation, releasing cytochrome c.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: Nephrotoxicity at therapeutic dose (0.8-1.5 mM) driven by IMPase inhibition (IC50 0.3-0.6 mM), causing myo-inositol depletion critical for renal AQP2 trafficking and osmoregulation.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: 2:** *Nephrotoxicity arises from intracellular [Li⁺] trapping in renal principal cells (2–20× plasma levels) due to ENaC-mediated uptake and poor Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase efflux, exceeding IMPase Ki (~0.8 mM) an
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Chronic IMPase block reduces IP1 hydrolysis, depleting inositol for phosphoinositide synthesis needed in proximal tubule cells under hyperosmotic stress.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: ENaC admits Li⁺ with P_Li/P_Na ≥1, but basolateral Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase extrudes Li⁺ ~10× slower than Na⁺, causing accumulation to 2–16 mM at 0.8 mM plasma, triggering IMPase inhibition and lysosomal stress.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: The dose-response curve for nephrotoxicity follows a Hill coefficient >1 (n ≈ 2–3), reflecting cooperative depletion of inositol pools, creating a steep threshold rather than gradual toxicity onset.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: Nephrotoxicity exhibits a sharp, non-linear dose-response (Hill coefficient > 1.5) because intracellular Li⁺ accumulation past a critical threshold (~2-3 mM) triggers cooperative, catastrophic events
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Inositol pool depletion is nonlinear — IMPase inhibition must exceed a threshold before phosphoinositide recycling collapses, producing apparent cooperativity in the toxicity dose-response.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: Beyond simple enzyme inhibition, supraphysiological intracellular cation levels trigger stress responses that function as all-or-none switches, amplifying cellular damage in a highly cooperative manne

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: Cytoprotective CBD (EC50 2-3.7 μM via TRPV1/2) dominates daytime (hyperpolarized ψ closes VDAC1, blocking cytotoxicity); nighttime flip via open VDAC1.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: The therapeutic window for a neuroprotective VDAC1 ligand like CBD is practically non-existent due to off-target effects. The neuroprotective concentration range (~0.5x Kd ≈ 5.5 µM) is an order of mag
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Low-dose CBD modulates Ca2+/metabolite flux protectively; VDAC1 closure at -180 mV requires >Kd CBD for forced oligomerization.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: The separation between the on-target VDAC1 affinity and off-target CYP3A4 inhibition affinity is insufficient to meet the minimum therapeutic index of 10.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: THC β-arrestin recruitment EC50 > G-protein EC50 (bias factor ~3-5), so low occupancy (<30%) yields therapeutic cAMP inhibition without GRK2/βarr downregulation.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: 1:** The biphasic (inverted-U) dose-response of THC occurs because low CB1 occupancy (<20%) preferentially engages Gi/o-ERK-CREB-BDNF signaling, while high occupancy recruits β-arrestin-2, causing rec
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Biased agonism preserves receptor recycling (t1/2~hours) by limiting phosphorylation at low efficacy occupancy.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: Low-dose THC produces biased signaling at CB1, sustaining Gi/o coupling to ERK/CREB without triggering β-arrestin-mediated internalization, thereby upregulating BDNF.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: Hill coefficient n=1 for both effects governs hyperbolic switch; intracellular [Li] window [1-10]uM for peak protection before toxicity onset.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: Nephrotoxicity exhibits a sharp, non-linear dose-response (Hill coefficient > 1.5) because intracellular Li⁺ accumulation past a critical threshold (~2-3 mM) triggers cooperative, catastrophic events
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Non-cooperative binding to single sites (GSK3/IMPase); renal accumulation via transporters widens effective window gap.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: Beyond simple enzyme inhibition, supraphysiological intracellular cation levels trigger stress responses that function as all-or-none switches, amplifying cellular damage in a highly cooperative manne

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: Nephrotoxicity at therapeutic dose (0.8-1.5 mM) driven by IMPase inhibition (IC50 0.3-0.6 mM), causing myo-inositol depletion critical for renal AQP2 trafficking and osmoregulation.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: 3:** Nephrotoxicity involves a threshold/cooperative mechanism (effective Hill n ≈ 1.5–2.5) because damage requires simultaneous IMPase inhibition (Ki ~0.8 mM), disrupted AQP2 trafficking, and ER stre
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Chronic IMPase block reduces IP1 hydrolysis, depleting inositol for phosphoinositide synthesis needed in proximal tubule cells under hyperosmotic stress.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: (effective Hill n ≈ 1.5–2.5) because damage requires simultaneous IMPase inhibition (Ki ~0.8 mM), disrupted AQP2 trafficking, and ER stress — each independently insufficient.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: Lithium neuroprotection at low dose (<0.5 mM) primarily via partial GSK3β inhibition (IC50 1-2 mM), stabilizing β-catenin, upregulating BDNF and autophagy.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: 4:** The clinical therapeutic index (~2–3) dramatically underestimates the *brain-specific* TI because brain [Li⁺] at toxic plasma levels (~1.5 mM) remains ~1–1.8 mM — still below direct GSK-3β Ki — w
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Li+ mimics Mg2+ uncompetitively at GSK3β active site, reducing phosphorylation of pro-apoptotic substrates proportionally to dose.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: The organ-specific TI for brain neuroprotection vs. renal toxicity is ~10–20× when indexed to intracellular concentrations rather than plasma.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: Circadian depolarized ΔΨm (-165 mV nighttime) lowers CBD cytotoxic IC50 3-5x (to 3-5 μM from 15 μM daytime), enabling sub-Kd (11 μM) toxicity via VDAC1.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: The therapeutic window for a neuroprotective VDAC1 ligand like CBD is practically non-existent due to off-target effects. The neuroprotective concentration range (~0.5x Kd ≈ 5.5 µM) is an order of mag
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Depolarized ΔΨm favors VDAC1 open state (P_open >80%), enhancing CBD binding cooperativity (Hill n>1.5) and oligomerization for cyt c release.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: The separation between the on-target VDAC1 affinity and off-target CYP3A4 inhibition affinity is insufficient to meet the minimum therapeutic index of 10.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: The dose-dependent switch is governed by the biphasic modulation of inositol monophosphatase (IMPase) and GSK-3β; low-dose inhibition is submaximal (~20-40%) and activates pro-survival PI3K/Akt and Nr
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: 2:** Neuroprotection at low dose is mediated primarily by indirect GSK-3β inhibition via Akt-Ser9 phosphorylation amplification, with effective EC50 ~0.2–0.5 mM intracellular — achievable at plasma [L
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Partial IMPase/GSK-3β inhibition at low [Li+] (≤0.5 mM) causes mild, non-toxic stress that triggers adaptive transcription via Nrf2 and CREB, whereas high [Li+] (≥1 mM) causes severe phosphoinositide
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: Li⁺ inhibits PP1/PP2A-mediated dephosphorylation of Akt-phosphorylated GSK-3β-Ser9, creating a signal amplification loop where small [Li⁺] produces disproportionate GSK-3β suppression.

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: Dose-switch via tissue context: neurons activate Nrf2/BDNF (low-dose induced) buffering mild inositol depletion; renal cells lack robust compensation, amplifying toxicity.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: The primary mechanism for the dose-discrepancy is differential intracellular accumulation: kidney principal cells achieve 3-5x plasma [Li⁺] (therapeutic plasma 0.8 mM → ~3 mM intracellular), exceeding
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: Low Li triggers adaptive Nrf2 antioxidants and BDNF/TrkB survival in neurons (singular thread validated by lit.), absent in proximal tubules leading to ROS/fibrosis at same dose.
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: for the dose-discrepancy is differential intracellular accumulation: kidney principal cells achieve 3-5x plasma [Li⁺] (therapeutic plasma 0.8 mM → ~3 mM intracellular), exceeding the Ki for IMPase inh

cross_validated_singulars.statement_a: The tolerance crossover point is governed by first-order kinetics: therapeutic window persists while k_recycle + k_synthesis > k_int × fractional_occupancy. For CB1, k_recycle ≈ 0.02 min⁻¹, k_int ≈ 0.
cross_validated_singulars.statement_b: 1:** The biphasic (inverted-U) dose-response of THC occurs because low CB1 occupancy (<20%) preferentially engages Gi/o-ERK-CREB-BDNF signaling, while high occupancy recruits β-arrestin-2, causing rec
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_a: CB1 internalization follows agonist-driven β-arrestin-dependent endocytosis; at low occupancy, the internalization flux (k_int × occupied_receptors) remains below the constitutive recycling/synthesis
cross_validated_singulars.mechanism_b: Low-dose THC produces biased signaling at CB1, sustaining Gi/o coupling to ERK/CREB without triggering β-arrestin-mediated internalization, thereby upregulating BDNF.

independent_replications.statement_a: 3:** Sustained wellbeing requires *synergistic 2-AG signaling*: low-dose THC (≤2.5 mg/day) adds to tonic 2-AG without displacement, while high-dose THC (>10 mg/day) saturates CB1, reducing 2-AG access
independent_replications.statement_b: 1:** The biphasic (inverted-U) dose-response of THC occurs because low CB1 occupancy (<20%) preferentially engages Gi/o-ERK-CREB-BDNF signaling, while high occupancy recruits β-arrestin-2, causing rec
independent_replications.mechanism_a: Low-dose THC occupies CB1 without competing with 2-AG, preserving tonic signaling; high-dose THC displaces 2-AG, triggering MAGL-mediated degradation.
independent_replications.mechanism_b: Low-dose THC produces biased signaling at CB1, sustaining Gi/o coupling to ERK/CREB without triggering β-arrestin-mediated internalization, thereby upregulating BDNF.

independent_replications.statement_a: (Supporting SINGULAR thread) Neuronal BDNF/TrkB signaling is potentiated by low-dose lithium via GSK-3β inhibition and CREB activation, providing a robust compensatory pro-survival signal absent in re
independent_replications.statement_b: 2:** Neuroprotection at low dose is mediated primarily by indirect GSK-3β inhibition via Akt-Ser9 phosphorylation amplification, with effective EC50 ~0.2–0.5 mM intracellular — achievable at plasma [L
independent_replications.mechanism_a: Lithium-enhanced BDNF/TrkB signaling activates PI3K/Akt and ERK pathways, which converge on mTOR and Bcl-2 to suppress apoptosis and enhance autophagy, buffering against mild metabolic stress.
independent_replications.mechanism_b: Li⁺ inhibits PP1/PP2A-mediated dephosphorylation of Akt-phosphorylated GSK-3β-Ser9, creating a signal amplification loop where small [Li⁺] produces disproportionate GSK-3β suppression.
